{{about|the theological concept|the novel by Geraldine Brooks|People of the Book (novel)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2013}} {{Islam and iman}} '''People of the Book/Scripture''' ({{lang-ar|أهل الكتاب }} ′Ahl al-Kitāb) is an Islamic term referring to [[Jews]], [[Christians]], and [[Sabians]] and sometimes applied to members of other religions such as [[Zoroastrians]].<ref name=ODI>{{cite encyclopedia|title=Ahl al-Kitab|editor=John L. Esposito|encyclopedia=The Oxford Dictionary of Islam|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=Oxford|year=2014|url=http://www.oxfordreference.com/view/10.1093/acref/9780195125580.001.0001/acref-9780195125580-e-74|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170103171035/http://www.oxfordreference.com/view/10.1093/acref/9780195125580.001.0001/acref-9780195125580-e-74|archivedate=3 January 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref> It is also used in [[Judaism]] to refer to the [[Jewish people]] and by members of some Christian denominations to refer to themselves.
The Quran uses the term in reference to Jews, Christians and Sabians in a variety of contexts, from religious polemics to passages emphasizing community of faith between those who possess monotheistic scriptures. The term was later extended to other religious communities that fell under Muslim rule, including even polytheistic Indians. Historically, these communities were subject to the [[dhimma]] contract in an Islamic state.
In [[Judaism]] the term "People of the Book" ([[Hebrew language|Hebrew]]: עם הספר, ''Am HaSefer'')<ref>{{cite book|author=Kerry M. Olitzky, Ronald H. Isaacs|title=A Glossary of Jewish Life|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GCy77T7kpnkC&pg=PA217|page=217|publisher=Jason Aronson|year=1992}}</ref> has come to refer to the [[Jewish people]] and the [[Torah]].<ref name="Yahudi">{{cite book|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=G2YlLrQUgzsC&pg=PR14&dq=baptists+are+people+of+the+book&ct=result#v=onepage&q=baptists%20are%20people%20of%20the%20book&f=false|title =People of the Book: Christian Identity and Literary Culture|author=David Lyle Jeffrey|quote=Though first intended pejoratively, "People of the Book" in Jewish tradition came to be accepted with pride as a legitimate reference to a culture and religious identity rooted fundamentally in Torah, the original book of the Law. |publisher=William B. Eerdmans Publishing Company|accessdate = 2007-10-18}}</ref>
Members of some [[Christian denominations]], such as the [[Baptists]], [[Methodists]], [[Seventh-day Adventist Church]],<ref name="adventistworld.org">{{cite web |url=http://archives.adventistworld.org/issue.php?issue=2010-1002&page=11 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-06-14 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714163613/http://archives.adventistworld.org/issue.php?issue=2010-1002&page=11 |archivedate=14 July 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://pobpublications.com/about |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-07-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110628145450/http://pobpublications.com/about |archivedate=28 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> as well as [[Puritans]] and [[Shakers]], have embraced the term "People of the Book" in reference to themselves.<ref name="Baptist Church">{{cite book|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=tuuys4HxSzcC&pg=PA78&dq=Baptist+People+of+The+Book+Islam&ct=result#v=onepage&q&f=false|title =Three Monotheistic Faiths - Judaism, Christianity, Islam: An Analysis And Brief History|author=Dr. Andrea C. Paterson|quote=Baptists are "people of the Book". The Bible serves as a guide for faith and practice, instructing local churches and individual believers on faith, conduct, and polity. Scripture is also the final authority in determining faith and practice, and is the Word of God which is revealed to the Church in order that God's people may know God's will.|accessdate = 2007-10-18}}</ref><ref name="Denominations">{{cite book|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=G2YlLrQUgzsC&pg=PR14&dq=baptists+are+people+of+the+book&ct=result#v=onepage&q=baptists%20are%20people%20of%20the%20book&f=false|title =People of the Book: Christian Identity and Literary Culture|author=David Lyle Jeffrey|quote=Nor is it unusual that the badge should be worn proudly as one means of resisting further denigration: one need only think of Puritans, Methodists, Quakers, and Shakers. In fact, the first of these groups are foremost in the Christian tradition who claimed the term in question, proud themselves to be in their own way identified as "a People of the Book". In the early Christian experience the New Testament was added to the whole Jewish "Tanakh" (an acronym from ''T''orah, the Law, Nebi'im, the prophets, and ''K''ethubim, the other canonical writings). This larger anthology, which after St. Jerome's translation tended more and more to be bound up as a single volume, had for those to whom the Christian missionaries came bearing it all the import of a unified ''locus'' of authority: "''the'' Book". |publisher=William B. Eerdmans Publishing Company|accessdate = 2007-10-18}}</ref>
==In the Qur'an==
In the Quran the term "people of the book" refers to [[Jews]], [[Christians]], and [[Sabians]].<ref name=EI>{{Cite encyclopedia|author=Vajda, G | year= 2012 | title=Ahl al-Kitāb |encyclopedia=Encyclopaedia of Islam| edition=2nd|publisher=Brill |editors=P. Bearman, Th. Bianquis, C.E. Bosworth, E. van Donzel, W.P. Heinrichs|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1163/1573-3912_islam_SIM_0383|subscription=yes|volume=1|page=264}}</ref> The scriptures referred to in the Quran are the [[Torah]] (''at-tawraat''), the [[Psalms]] (''al-zabur'') and the [[Gospel]] (''al-injiil'').<ref name=EI/>
The Quran emphasizes the community of faith between possessors of monotheistic scriptures, and occasionally pays tribute to the religious and moral virtues of communities that have received earlier revelations, calling on Muhammad to ask them for information.<ref name=EI/> More often, reflecting the refusal of Jews and Christians in Muhammad's environment to accept his message, the Quran stresses their inability to comprehend the message they possess but do not put into practice and to appreciate that Muhammad's teaching fulfills that message.<ref name=EI/> The People of the Book are also referenced in the ''[[jizya]]'' verse (9:29),<ref name=EI/> which has received [[Jizya#In the Qur.27an|varied interpretations]].
==Later Islamic usage==
The use of the term was later extended to [[Zoroastrians]], [[Samaritans]], [[Mandeans]], and even polytheistic Indians.<ref name=ODI/><ref name=EI/>
Islamic scholars differ on whether [[Hinduism|Hindus]] are People of the Book.<ref name="hinduism">{{cite book | title = Sufi Essays | publisher = State University of New York Press | year = 1973 | isbn = 0-87395-233-2 | page = 139 | first = Seyyed Hossein | last = Nasr}}</ref> The [[Islamic conquest of India]] necessitated that the definition be revised, as most India's inhabitants were followers of the [[Indian religions]]. Many of the Muslim clergy of India considered Hindus as people of the book,<ref name="hinduism"/> and from [[Muhammad bin Qasim]] to [[Aurangzeb]], Muslim rulers were willing to consider Hindus as people of the book.<ref name="hinduism2_127">{{cite book | title = Hinduism and Islam in India: Caste, Religion, and Society from Antiquity to Early Modern Times | first = S. V. | last = Desika Char |publisher=Markus Wiener Publishers | year = 1997 | isbn = 1-55876-151-9 | page = 127}}</ref> Many Muslims did not treat Hindus as pagans or idol-worshipers,<ref name="hinduism"/> although Hinduism does not include Adam, Eve, nor the various prophets of Abrahamic religions.
[[Buddhism]] does not explicitly recognize a monotheistic God or the concept of prophet-hood. Muslims however had at one point accorded them the status of "people of the Book", and [[Al-Biruni]] wrote of Buddha as the prophet "Burxan".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://studybuddhism.com/web/en/archives/e-books/unpublished_manuscripts/historical_interaction/pt3/history_cultures_18.html|author=Alexander Berzin|title=The Historical Interaction between the Buddhist and Islamic Cultures before the Mongol Empire|year=2006|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160629190852/http://studybuddhism.com/web/en/archives/e-books/unpublished_manuscripts/historical_interaction/pt3/history_cultures_18.html|archivedate=29 June 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Dhimmi==
{{Main|Dhimmi}}
''Dhimmi'' is a historical<ref name=Campo/> term referring to the status accorded to People of the Book living in an [[Islamic state]].<ref name=Campo>{{cite encyclopedia |title=dhimmi |encyclopedia=Encyclopedia of Islam |editor=Juan Eduardo Campo |pages=194–195 |publisher=Infobase Publishing |date=2010-05-12 |quote= "Dhimmis are non-Muslims who live within Islamdom and have a regulated and protected status. ... In the modern period, this term has generally has occasionally been resuscitated, but it is generally obsolete."}}</ref> The word literally means "protected person."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/dhimmi|title=Definition of DHIMMI|author=|date=|website=www.merriam-webster.com|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150518075744/http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/dhimmi|archivedate=18 May 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> According to scholars, dhimmis had their rights fully protected in their communities, but as citizens in the Islamic state, had certain restrictions,<ref name=Bennett>{{Cite book|title=Muslims and Modernity: An Introduction to the Issues and Debates|author=[[Clinton Bennett]]|publisher=[[Continuum International Publishing Group]]|year=2005|isbn=082645481X|page=163|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=D0vYYovH7OQC|accessdate=2012-07-07}}</ref> and it was obligatory for them to pay the [[jizya]] tax, which complemented the [[zakat]], or alms, paid by the Muslim subjects.<ref>{{cite book |last=Glenn |first= H. Patrick |author-link=H. Patrick Glenn |year=2007 |title=Legal Traditions of the World |publisher=[[Oxford University Press]] |pages=218–219 |quote=A Dhimmi is a non-Muslim subject of a state governed in accordance to sharia law. The term connotes an obligation of the state to protect the individual, including the individual's life, property, and freedom of religion and worship, and required loyalty to the empire, and a poll tax known as the jizya, which complemented the Islamic tax paid by the Muslim subjects, called Zakat.}}</ref> Dhimmis were excluded from specific duties assigned to Muslims, and did not enjoy certain political rights reserved for Muslims, but were otherwise equal under the laws of property, contract, and obligation.<ref>H. Patrick Glenn, ''Legal Traditions of the World''. [[Oxford University Press]], 2007, p. 219.</ref><ref>The French scholar Gustave Le Bon (the author of ''La civilisation des Arabes'') writes "that despite the fact that the incidence of taxation fell more heavily on a Muslim than a non-Muslim, the non-Muslim was free to enjoy equally well with every Muslim all the privileges afforded to the citizens of the state. The only privilege that was reserved for the Muslims was the seat of the caliphate, and this, because of certain religious functions attached to it, which could not naturally be discharged y a non-Muslim." Mun'im Sirry (2014), ''Scriptural Polemics: The Qur'an and Other Religions'', p.179. [[Oxford University Press]]. {{ISBN|978-0199359363}}.</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Abou El Fadl|first1=Khaled|authorlink=Khaled Abou El Fadl|title=The Great Theft: Wrestling Islam from the Extremists|date=2007|publisher=[[HarperOne]]|isbn=978-0061189036|page=204|quote = According to the dhimma status system, non-Muslims must pay a poll tax in return for Muslim protection and the privilege of living in Muslim territory. Per this system, non-Muslims are exempt from military service, but they are excluded from occupying high positions that involve dealing with high state interests, like being the president or prime minister of the country. In Islamic history, non-Muslims did occupy high positions, especially in matters that related to fiscal policies or tax collection.}}</ref>
Under [[sharia]], the dhimmi communities were usually subjected to their own special laws, rather than some of the laws which were applicable only to the Muslim community. For example, the [[Jews|Jewish]] community in Medina was allowed to have its own [[beit din|Halakhic courts]],<ref name="Cohen">{{cite book|title=Under Crescent and Cross: The Jews in the Middle Ages|author=[[Mark R. Cohen|Cohen, Mark R.]] |publisher=[[Princeton University Press]]|year=1995|isbn=0-691-01082-X |page=74 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=fgbib5exskUC&printsec=frontcover&dq=cohen+Under+Crescent+and+Cross&q|accessdate=April 10, 2010 |ref=harv}}</ref> and the [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] [[millet (Ottoman Empire)|millet system]] allowed its various dhimmi communities to rule themselves under separate legal courts. These courts did not cover cases that involved religious groups outside of their own community, or capital offences. Dhimmi communities were also allowed to engage in certain practices that were usually forbidden for the Muslim community, such as the [[Islamic dietary laws|consumption of alcohol and pork]].<ref>Al-Misri, ''Reliance of the Traveler'' (edited and translated by [[Nuh Ha Mim Keller]]), p. 608. Amana Publications, 1994.</ref><ref>Al-Misri, ''Reliance of the Traveler'' (ed. and trans. Nuh Ha Mim Keller), pp. 977, 986. Amana Publications, 1994.</ref>{{sfn|Ghazi|Kalin|Kamali|2013|pp=240–1}}
Historically, dhimmi status was originally applied to [[Jews]], [[Christian]]s, and [[Sabians]]. This status later also came to be applied to [[Zoroastrianism|Zoroastrians]], [[Hindu]]s, [[Jainism|Jains]] and [[Buddhism|Buddhists]].<ref>{{cite book|author=Wael B. Hallaq|authorlink = Wael Hallaq|title=Sharī'a: Theory, Practice, Transformations|year=2009|publisher=Cambridge University Press (Kindle edition)|page=327 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=[[Annemarie Schimmel]]|year=2004|page=107|title=The Empire of the Great Mughals: History, Art and Culture|isbn=978-1861891853|quote=The conqueror [[Muhammad bin Qasim|Muhammad Ibn Al Qasem]] gave both Hindus and Buddhists the same status as the Christians, Jews and Sabaeans the Middle East. They were all "dhimmi" ('protected people')}}</ref><ref name=bonner>{{cite book|author=Michael Bonner|title=Jihad in Islamic History|publisher=Princeton University Press (Kindle edition)|year=2008|page= 89}}</ref> Moderate Muslims generally reject the dhimma system as inappropriate for the age of nation-states and democracies.<ref name="El Fadl">"[…] the overwhelming majority of moderate Muslims reject the dhimma system as ahistorical, in the sense that it is inappropriate for the age of nation-states and democracies." {{cite book|last1=[[Khaled Abou El Fadl|Abou El Fadl]]|first1=[[Khaled Abou El Fadl|Khaled]]|title=The Great Theft: Wrestling Islam from the Extremists|date=January 23, 2007|publisher=HarperOne|isbn=978-0061189036|page=214}}</ref>
== Judaism == Thirty-one times in the Koran Jews are referred to as "people of the book."<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Albayrak,|first=Ishmael|date=2008|title=The People of the Book in the Qur'an|url=|journal=Islamic Studies|volume=47:3|pages=301–325|via=}}</ref> However before the rise of Islam, during Biblical times, Levitical scribes redacted and canonized the book of books.<ref>{{Cite book|title=People of the book: canon, meaning, and authority|last=Halbertal|first=Moshe|publisher=Harvard University Press|year=1997|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> In the transition from what has been called "text to tradition," Efforts are made to try to reconstruct the archival repositories for these ancient textual collections in addition to sifrei Yichusin (genealogical texts).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://156ebc5c-a-62cb3a1a-s-sites.googlegroups.com/site/mtevansco/temp/levydfull3.pdf?attachauth=ANoY7cpoqeFR1VkucKyuP-8DN83hOO8kcWENLxQqU_COvL7tIvmEsgy7ICrXAiO3Qa0eu1b4DjRL_WktWT4V6sluKYHT7gEGKizCeU_LzyNatMWbAANuyyylOj3moXP4qUzcyH3OGuGjTKrwC8TBTCNP-JYCNKwhHzOzjShjOyIn3vVQqeY2Rh_ntp2TgxqEg7HD7-q2up5WQH6miFYqrdQUJxscMZvyrQ%3D%3D&attredirects=0|title=Ancient to Modern Jewish Classification Systems: A Historical Overview|last=Levy|first=David B|date=2001|access-date=}}</ref> The Babylonian Talmud Baba Batra 14b-14b describes the order of biblical books. Indeed Rashi himself comments on the mishnaic statement, "Moses received the Torah from Sinai" by noting since the text does not say "ha-torah" (the written torah) but Torah (in general) this refers to both the written torah (24 books of the Old Testament) and the oral torah, which in Rabbinic theology are co-terminous<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Soloveitchik|first=Haym|date=1994|title=Rupture and Reconstruction:The Transformation of Contemporary Orthodoxy|url=|journal=Tradition: A Journal of Orthodox Jewish Thought|volume=28:4|pages=64–130|via=}}</ref>, as suggested by Soloveitchik who notes a recent trend in the Artscroll generation to eclipse oral transmission with written translations. Scholars of antiquity and the early middle ages do know about the canonization process of the Tanakh<ref>{{Cite book|title="The Hebrew Bible Canon" in The Book of Books|last=Lundberg,|first=Marilyn J|publisher=|year=2013|isbn=|location=|pages=20–25}}</ref> (the Hebrew Bible) and the redaction processes of the Talmudim and Midrashim.<ref>{{Cite book|title="The Bible in the Talmud and Midrash" in The Book of Books|last=Schiffman|first=Lawrence|publisher=|year=2013|isbn=|location=|pages=36–39}}</ref> Thus the interplay between written text and orality is essential in trying to reconstruct the textual collections of Jewish texts in the middle ages<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://databases.jewishlibraries.org/node/49232|title=Jewish Archives and Libraries in the Middle Ages and the Medieval Educational Curriculum|last=Levy|first=David|date=2013|website=|access-date=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170911023842/http://databases.jewishlibraries.org/node/49232|archivedate=11 September 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref> and modernity.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://databases.jewishlibraries.org/node/51186|title=19th and 20th Century Scholarly Judaica Research Librarians, and Judaica Collections|last=Levy|first=David|date=2016|website=|access-date=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170910221049/http://databases.jewishlibraries.org/node/51186|archivedate=10 September 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Rabbinic tradition has demonstrated a reverence, respect, and love for sacred divinely revealed "text," both written and oral in the process of the chain of transmission (the masorah). Indeed the metaphor of the book is marshaled in Talmudic Tractate Rosh Hashanah, that on Rosh Hashanah the fate of each person for the year is written, on Yom Kippur sealed, and on Hoshanah Rabbah the angels of the heavenly court deliver the verdict to God's archive.
The Hai Gaon in 998 in Pumbeditah comments, "Three possessions should you prize- a field, a friend, and a book." However the Hai Gaon mentions that a book is more reliable than even friends for sacred books span across time, indeed can express external ideas, that transcend time itself.
The Spanish philosopher, physician, and poet Rabbi Yehudah HaLevi writes of the importance of books by commenting, "My pen is my harp and my lyre, my library is my garden and orchard."<ref>{{Cite book|title=Diyan: ve-hu sefer kolel kol shirei Yehudah ha-Levi.. im hagahot u-ve'urim ve-'im mavo me-et Hayim Brodi|last=Brodi|first=Hayim|publisher=bi-derus Tsevi Hirsch b.R. Yitshak Ittskovski|year=1896–1930|isbn=|location=Berlin|pages=166, line 37–8}}</ref>
The Provencal scholar Rabbi Yehudah ibn Tibbon (Adler recension) further elaborates on the importance of his library by commenting, "Make books your companions; let your bookshelves be your gardens: bask in their beauty, gather their fruit, pluck their roses, take their spices and myrrh. And when your soul be wary, change form one garden to garden, and from one prospect to prospect."<ref>{{Cite book|title=Ermahnungsschreiben des Jehudah ibn Tibbon|last=Steinschneider|first=Moritz|publisher=Berlin|year=1852|isbn=|location=|pages=6–12}}</ref>
The Spanish statesman Rabbi Shmuel ha-Nagid writes, "the wise of heart will abandon ease and pleasures for in his library he will find treasures."<ref>{{Cite book|title=Hebrew Ethical Wills|last=Abraham|first=Israel|publisher=JPS|year=1926|isbn=|location=|pages=64}}</ref> Rabbi Abraham ibn Daud writes in his sefer ha-qabbala about rabbi Shmuel ha-Nagid that he had sofrim who copied Mishnah and Talmudim, and he used to donated these commissioned core texts to students who could not afford to purchase them."<ref>{{Cite book|title=Meḳorot le-toldot ha-ḥinukh be-Yiśraʼel|last=Assaf|first=Simcha|publisher=Tel-Aviv, Dvir|year=1930–1954|isbn=|location=|pages=vol 4, p. 17}}</ref>
Rabbi Yitzchak ben Yosef of Corbeil (ca 1280, France) in his Sefer Mitzvot Qatan composed in 1276 outlines a detailed strategy for the dissemination of his texts by asserting that every community should finance a copy of his halkhic code and keep it for public consultation.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Be-ohole Yaʻaḳov : peraḳim me-ḥaye ha-tarbut shel ha-Yehudim bi-yeme ha-benayim|last=Asaf|first=Simcha|publisher=Yerushalayim : Mosad ha-Rav Ḳuḳ|year=1943|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref>
Rabbi Shimon ben Zemach Duran (Tashbaz) in his introduction to his halakhic code, Zohar HaRakiah, writes, "When the wise man lies down with his fathers he leaves behind him a treasured and organized blessing: books that enlighten like the brilliance of the firmament (Daniel 12:3) and that extend peace like an eternal flowing river (ISa 66:12)."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.hebrewbooks.org/3982|title=Hebrewbooks.org Sefer Zohar Ha-Rakiah|last=Duran|first=Shimon|date=|website=|access-date=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170604085431/http://hebrewbooks.org/3982|archivedate=4 June 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
The love and reverence for Jewish books is seen in Jewish law. It is not permissible for a sacred Jewish text to lie on the ground and if by accident a book is dropped to the floor it should be picked up and given a kiss. A Jewish book is not to be left open unless it is being read, nor is it to be held upside down.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Shulchan Arukh:Yoreah Deah 277|last=Karo|first=Yosef|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> It is not permitted to place a book of lesser sanctity on top of a book of higher holiness, so for example one must never place any book on top of the Tanakh. If one says to someone, "Please hand me this book," the book should be given with the right hand and not with the left hand."<ref>{{Cite book|title=Babylonian Talmud: Maseket Sofrim 83|last=|first=|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> If two men are walking and one who is carrying a sacred books should be given the courtesy of entering and leaving the room first, as the second is enjoined to pursue knowledge."<ref>{{Cite book|title=Likutei Mahril 118|last=|first=|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> Rabbi David ibn Zimra of the 16th century comments that "if one buys a new book he should recite the benediction of the She-Heheyanu."<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Life and Times of Rabbi David ibn Zimra|last=Goldman|first=Israel|publisher=|year=1970|isbn=|location=New York : Jewish Theological Seminary of America|pages=32}}</ref>
==Christian usage== In the [[early Christian]] experience the [[New Testament]] was added to the whole [[Old Testament]], which after [[Jerome]]'s translation tended more and more to be bound up as a [[Bible|single volume]], and was accepted as a unified ''locus'' of authority: "''the'' Book", as some contemporary authors refer to it.<ref name="Denominations"/> Many [[Christian missionaries]] in Africa, Asia and in the [[New World]], developed writing systems for indigenous people and then provided them with a written [[Bible translations|translation of the Bible]].<ref name="Perry-Chase-Jacob-Jacob">{{cite book |last1=Perry |first1=Marvin |last2=Chase |first2=Myrna |last3=Jacob |first3=Margaret |last4=Jacob |first4=James |last5=Daly |first5=Jonathan W. |last6=Von Laue |first6=Theodore H. |year=2014 |title=Western Civilization: Ideas, Politics, and Society |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jy5BBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA635&lpg=PA635 |volume=Volume II: Since 1600 |edition=11th |location=Boston, MA |publisher=[[Cengage Learning]] |page=635 |isbn=978-1-305-09142-9 |lccn=2014943347 |oclc=898154349 |quote=In the nineteenth century, in contrast to the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries, Europeans, except for missionaries, rarely adopted the customs or learned the languages of local people. They had little sense that other cultures and other peoples deserved respect. Many Westerners believed that it was their Christian duty to set an example and to educate others. Missionaries were the first to meet and learn about many peoples and the first to develop writing for those without a written language. Christian missionaries were ardently opposed to slavery.... |accessdate =2016-02-01 |ref=harv}}</ref><ref name="Language">{{cite book|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=G2YlLrQUgzsC&pg=PR14&dq=baptists+are+people+of+the+book&ct=result#v=onepage&q=baptists%20are%20people%20of%20the%20book&f=false|title =People of the Book: Christian Identity and Literary Culture|author=David Lyle Jeffrey|quote="People of the Book" unsurprisingly translates many an early vernacular name for Christian missionaries among African, Asian, and Native American people of both hemispheres. The fact that these missionaries put enormous effort into reducing the language of these people to writing so as to provide a written translation of the Bible - an activity which, under such organizations as the Wycliffe Bible Translators and the United Bible Societies, has resulted in at least part of the Christian Bible now being available in 2,100 languages - has lent an identification with the phrase among evangelical Christians in particular as strong as pertains among Jews. This identity comprises the Christian converts among evangelized cultures, the more recently evangelized the more natural so, since for many of them, just as for the English-speaking people, the first written texts ever produced in their language have been a portion of the Bible.|publisher=[[William B. Eerdmans Publishing Company]]|accessdate = 2007-10-18}}</ref> As a result of this work, "People of the Book" became the usual vernacular locution to refer to [[Christians]] among many African, Asian, and Native American people of both hemispheres.<ref name="Language"/> The work of organizations such as the [[Wycliffe Bible Translators]] and the [[United Bible Societies]] has resulted in Bibles being available in 2,100 languages. This fact has further promoted an identification with the phrase among Christians themselves.<ref name="Denominations"/> Christian converts among [[Evangelism|evangelized]] cultures, in particular, have the strongest identification with the term "People of the Book". This arises because the first written text produced in their native language, as with the English-speaking peoples, has often been the Bible.<ref name="Language"/> Many [[Christian denominations|denominations]], such as [[Baptists]] and the [[Methodist Church]], which are notable for their mission work,<ref name="Missionary Work">{{cite book|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=M0cgmaRqH_IC&pg=PA29&dq=methodism+and+its+missionary+work&ct=result#v=onepage&q=methodism%20and%20its%20missionary%20work&f=false|title =American Methodism|publisher = S.S. Scranton & Co.|quote=But the most noticeable feature of British Methodism is its missionary spirit, and its organized, effective missionary work. It takes the lead of all other churches in missionary movements. From its origin, Methodism has been characterized for its zeal in propagandism. It has always been missionary.|accessdate = 2007-10-18}}</ref> have therefore embraced the term "People of the Book".<ref name="Baptist Church"/><ref name="Denominations"/>
As stated on its official world website, the Seventh-day Adventist Church (SDA) also embraces the term People of the Book.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.adventist.org/bible-study/index.html|title=Bible Study|author=|date=8 December 2016|website=www.adventist.org|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110730050119/http://www.adventist.org/bible-study/index.html|archivedate=30 July 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref> As also noted in its official flagship publication ''Adventist World'' (February 2010 edition), it is claimed that prominent Islamic leaders have endorsed Seventh-day Adventists as the Qur'an's true People of the Book.<ref name="adventistworld.org"/>

The '''Bishop of Ostia''' is the head of the [[suburbicarian diocese]] of [[Ostia Antica (district)|Ostia]], one of the seven [[suburbicarian sees]] of [[Diocese of Rome|Rome]]. The position is now attached to the post of [[Dean of the College of Cardinals]], as it has been since 1150,[http://www.fiu.edu/~mirandas/guide-iv.htm The Cardinals of the Holy Roman Church - Guide to documents and events (76-2005)] This statement of Miranda is unsourced. Moreover, Rudolf Hüls (pp.79-80) has demonstrated that the perpetual leadership of the Bishop of Ostia is not the case, but that the principle of seniority held true in Rome as it did elsewhere (cf. Hüls, pp. 77-78), before and after Pope Eugenius III. It was not until Pope Paul IV that the Deanship and the Bishopric of Ostia were tied together, in his Bull of 22 August 1555, ''Cum venerabiles''. {{cite book|title=Bullarum diplomatum et privilegiorum sanctorum Romanorum pontificum Taurensis editio|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2V7-MMnXzSoC|volume=Tomus sextus (6)|year=1860|publisher=Seb. Franco|language=Latin|pages=502–504}} with the actual governance of the diocese entrusted to the [[Cardinal Vicar|Vicar General of Rome]]. Ostia and Velletri, "Ostia e Velletri" in Italian, was a single suburbicarian diocese from 1105 to 1914. In 1914, [[Roman Catholic Suburbicarian Diocese of Velletri-Segni|Velletri]] (now Velletri-Segni) was split off as a separate suburbicarian diocese. Starting then, a new Dean would add the see of Ostia to the suburbicarian see he already had. ==List of bishops== ===Bishops of Ostia, to 1057=== {{div col|colwidth=22em}} *[Maximus (259)]According to the ''Passio S. Ippolito, documento romanzesco e pieno di errori." :'''...''' *Maximus (313)Maximus of Ostia was present at the Roman synod of October 313, conducted by [[Pope Miltiades]]. J. D. Mansi (ed.) {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2013}} [[File:Iwa jinja 11.JPG|thumb|275 px|A row of ''sessha'' at [[Iwa Shrine]], [[Hyōgo Prefecture]]]] {{nihongo|'''Sessha'''|摂社|auxiliary shrine}} and {{nihongo|'''massha'''|末社|undershrine}}, also called {{nihongo|'''eda-miya'''|枝宮|branch shrines}}<ref name="IK">Iwanami {{nihongo|[[Kōjien]]|広辞苑}} Japanese dictionary, 6th Edition (2008), DVD version.</ref> (collectively known as {{nihongo|'''setsumatsusha'''|摂末社|}}<ref name="sgk">{{cite web|url=http://100.yahoo.co.jp/detail/%E6%91%82%E7%A4%BE%E3%83%BB%E6%9C%AB%E7%A4%BE/|archive-url=https://archive.is/20121219003453/http://100.yahoo.co.jp/detail/%E6%91%82%E7%A4%BE%E3%83%BB%E6%9C%AB%E7%A4%BE/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=19 December 2012|title=Sessha, massha|last=Mure|first=Jin|publisher=Shokagukan|language=Japanese|accessdate=9 March 2010}}</ref><ref group="note">The term ''setsumatsusha'' is the combination of the two terms ''sessha'' and ''massha''.</ref>) are small or miniature shrines entrusted to the care of a larger shrine, generally due to some deep connection with the enshrined ''[[kami]]''.<ref name="yahoo">{{cite web|url=http://100.yahoo.co.jp/detail/%E6%91%82%E7%A4%BE%E3%83%BB%E6%9C%AB%E7%A4%BE/|archive-url=https://archive.is/20121219003453/http://100.yahoo.co.jp/detail/%E6%91%82%E7%A4%BE%E3%83%BB%E6%9C%AB%E7%A4%BE/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=19 December 2012|title=Sessha - Massha|publisher=Yahoo! Japan|language=Japanese|accessdate=5 December 2009}}</ref>
The two terms used to have legally different meanings, but are today [[synonyms]]. ''Setsumatsusha'' can lie either {{nihongo|inside|境内摂末社|keidai setsumatsusha}} or {{nihongo|outside|境外摂末社|keigai setsumassha}} the main shrine's premises. ''Setsumatsusha'' are usually 1x1 ''[[Ken (architecture)|ken]]'' in size. They can however be as small as [[beehives]] or relatively large and have 1x2, 1x3 or even, in one case, 1x7 bays.<ref name="jami">{{cite web|title=JAANUS|url=http://www.aisf.or.jp/~jaanus/deta/m/misedanazukuri.htm|website=aisf.or.jp|accessdate=15 March 2016}}</ref>
==History== The practice of building ''sessha'' and ''massha'' shrines within a ''jinja'' predates [[recorded history|written history]]. The earliest ''setsumatsusha'' usually had some strong connection to the history of the area or the family of the enshrined ''kami''.
During the [[Heian period]], [[Ise Shrine]] used to make a distinction between the two types based on whether a shrine belonged to the [[Engishiki]] ''Jinmyōchō'' list (''sessha'') or to the ''Enryaku gishikichō'' list (''massha'').<ref name="Eos">{{cite web|url=http://eos.kokugakuin.ac.jp/modules/xwords/entry.php?entryID=266|title=Sessha, Massha|last=Mori |first=Mizue|publisher=Encyclopedia of Shinto|accessdate=5 December 2009}}</ref>
From the [[History of Japan#Feudal Japan (1185-1603)|Japanese Middle Ages]] onwards, at other shrines popular ''kami'' like [[Hachiman]], [[Inari (mythology)|Inari]] or {{nihongo|Gozu Tennō|牛頭天王}} were often enshrined<ref group="note">Through a process called ''[[kanjō]]''</ref> in ''setsumatsusha'', but no clear distinction between the two terms was made. From the [[Meiji period]] to the [[Second World War]], a shrine dedicated to family members of a ''kami'', to the {{nihongo|violent side of a kami|荒魂|aramitama}}, or the ''kami'' of the region where the main shrine was, were to be considered ''sessha'' with a higher rank than the rest, which were called ''massha''.<ref name="Eos"/> When the {{nihongo|''[[Modern system of ranked Shinto Shrines|shakaku]]''|社格}} shrine ranking system was abolished in 1946, legally the distinction disappeared, but both terms remained in use out of habit.
==Architectural style== [[File:Sanko-jinja massha.jpeg|thumb|A ''massha'' at [[Sankō Shrine]] in [[Ōsaka]]]]
Being true shrines, ''setsumatsusha'' have most features other types of shrines have, including doors and often stairs. However, the {{nihongo|''Misedana-zukuri''|見世棚造 or 店棚造|showcase style}} is a style normally used only in ''sessha'' and ''massha''. It owes its name to the fact that, unlike other shrine styles, it doesn't feature a stairway at its entrance, and the veranda is completely flat.<ref name="jami"/> Miniature stairways can however be present. They can be either {{nihongo|''[[tsumairi]]''|妻入}}, that is have the entrance under the gable, or, more frequently, {{nihongo|''[[hirairi]]''|平入}}, that is, have the entrance on the side parallel to the roof's ridge (see examples in the gallery). Apart from the lack of a staircase, such shrines belong to the ''[[nagare-zukuri]]'' or ''[[kasuga-zukuri]]'' styles.
==Architectural examples==
<gallery> File:Hinomisaki-jinja sessha.jpg|A large ''sessha'' File:Kagami-no-miya-jinja. 01JPG.JPG|A ''massha'' at [[Ise Shrine]] File:Katsuragi-jinja (Gose, Nara) massha.jpg|A row of ''massha'' File:Iwashimizu Hachimangu setummasha6.jpg|A ''hirairi'' ''sessha'' File:Aguchi-jinja setsumassha2.jpg|A ''tsumairi'' ''sessha'' </gallery>

'''Spatika Lingam or Crystal Lingam''' '''or Crystal Shivling''' is a type of [[Lingam]] made from [[quartz]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.himalayanacademy.com/monastery/temples/iraivan/in-the-news|title=Iraivan Temple In the News|website=Himalayanacademy|access-date=15 February 2018|date=28 January 2012|author=P G K Menon}}</ref> Spatika Lingam is called sphatika Sivalingam(Tamil - படிகக்கல் லிங்கம்) ({{Lang-sa|स्फटिक शिवलिंग}}) in Sanskrit.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.himalayanacademy.com/blog/taka/2017/01/07/a-clear-crystal-vision-the-story-of-iraivans-lingam/|title=A Clear Crystal Vision: The Story of Iraivan’s Lingam}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://astronavprayas.wordpress.com/2015/08/12/%E0%A4%B8%E0%A5%8D%E0%A4%AB%E0%A4%9F%E0%A4%BF%E0%A4%95-%E0%A4%B6%E0%A4%BF%E0%A4%B5%E0%A4%B2%E0%A4%BF%E0%A4%82%E0%A4%97/|title=स्फटिक शिवलिंग}}</ref> Sphatikam ({{Lang-sa|स्फटिक}}) in Sanskrit means "made of crystal, crystalline", referring to quartz and [[alum]].<ref>{{citation | author=[[Monier Monier-Williams|Monier Williams]] | title=A Sanskrit-English Dictionary | entry=Sphatika | publisher=Clarendon Press | year=1872 | page=1151c | url=https://archive.org/details/1872sanskriten00moniuoft}}</ref>[[File:Spatika Lingam illuminated by laser.png|thumb|Spatika lingam in the [[Kadavul Temple]]|389x389px]]
==Sphatikam == Sphatikam is a semi-precious [[gemstone]]. There are many different varieties of sphatikam. High quality quartz crystals are single-crystal silica with optical or electronic properties that make them suitable for [[hardstone carving]]s. The Hindu temples in South India use this semi-precious mineral for making Shiva Lingams. Sphatikam beads are made from translucent rose quartz are cut and polished as beads. Each bead is about ten millimeters in diameter. It is good conductor of heat. Hence people wear sphatikam jewelry (mala) to keep their body cool. Some other people claim that these beads have healing properties.
==Sphatika Lingam in scriptures== In Hindu Shiva temples, Saiva [[Āgama (Hinduism)|Agamas]]([[Shaivism|Shaivism's]] [[Āgama (Hinduism)|Agamas]]) allows worshiping [[Shiva|Lord Shiva]] in the form of Sphatika Lingam or Crystal Lingam. The Saiva [[Āgama (Hinduism)|Agamas]] says "one can worship this Great [[Shiva|God Shiva]] in the form of a Lingam made of mud or sand, of cow dung or wood, of bronze or black granite stone. But the purest and most sought-after form is the [[quartz]] crystal (Sphatika), a natural stone not carved by man but made by nature, gathered molecule by molecule over hundreds, thousands or millions of years, grown as a living body grows, but infinitely more slowly. Such a creation of nature is itself a miracle worthy of worship."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.himalayanacademy.com/blog/taka/2017/01/07/a-clear-crystal-vision-the-story-of-iraivans-lingam/|title=A Clear Crystal Vision: The Story of Iraivan’s Lingam|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
==Sphatika Lingam in Temples== Sphatika Lingam is representing the icon of Lord Nataraja. The Sphatika Lingams are protected in the sanctum sanctorum of Lord Shiva. Hindu priests offer milk, water, or [[vibhuti]] [[abhisheka]] to the Sphatika Lingam. They also chant 108 times [[Om Namah Shivaya|Shiva Panchakshari Mantra]] . It is believed that Sphatika Lingam removes all curses and negative karma and will enhance ones confidence and power.
===Thillai Natarajah Temple, Chidambaram=== [[Nataraja Temple, Chidambaram|Thillai Natarajah Temple, Chidambaram]] is considered as one of the most ancient and most celebrated of Shiva temples in India. [[File:Chidambaram Nataraja temple tank.JPG|thumb|right|Chidambaram Temple]]Saivites attach great religious as well as historic and cultural significance with this temple. In this temple Lord Shiva is an embodiment of the infinite space. Chidambaram temple is associated with Lord Nataraja, or Shiva in his Ananda Tandava pose (the Cosmic Dance of bliss) in the cosmic golden hall (Ponnambalam) and the hall of consciousness (Chit Sabha).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://tamilnadu.com/temples/thillai-nataraja-kovil.html|title=Thillai Nataraja Kovil|publisher= Tamilnadu.com|date=11 February 2013}}</ref> Lord Shiva is also worshipped in this temple as "formless form" and this fact is being understood as Chidambara Rahasyam. This temple is known for its Akasa Lingam, an embodiment of Shiva as the formless Space.The Hindu monk Adi Sankara is said to have presented a Sphatika Lingam which is still under worship in this temple. This Sphatika Lingam, instituted at Chitsabha, is being represented as Lord Chandramauleeswara (A form of Lord Shiva). Also in the Chitsabha are images of Ratnasabhapati (Nataraja of Ruby), Swarnakarshana Bhairavar, Mukhalingam etc.
===Kadavul Temple, Kauai, Hawaii, USA=== [[Kadavul Temple|Kadavul HinduTemple]] is a traditional Sri Lankan style temple dedicated to [[Shiva|Lord Shiva]] and was established in 1973 in [[Kauai]], [[Hawaii]], USA. [[File:Kadavul Temple Outside.jpg|thumb|Kadavul temple outside|213x213px]]
[[Shiva|Lord Shiva]] is enshrined in the main sanctum in the form of [[Nataraja]] and a crystal [[Lingam|Sivalingam]]. In front of Shiva's sanctum is a 300-Kg, 3-foot-tall, naturally formed sphatika [[Lingam|Sivalingam]] , believed to be the ''largest six-sided, single-pointed crystal ever found.''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.himalayanacademy.com/monastery/temples/iraivan/in-the-news|title=Iraivan Temple In the News|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> [[File:Kadavul temple inside.jpg|thumb|Inside kadavul temple, walls lined with 108 Idols of [[Nataraja]]|left]] This Shiva Lingam is being temporarily installed in [[Kadavul Temple|Kadavul HinduTemple]], where a ruby-red, low-power laser beam illumines it.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.hinduismtoday.com/modules/smartsection/item.php?itemid=453|title=Rare Crystal Siva Lingam Arrives At Hawaii Temple|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> In future this Saptika lingam would be housed in the hand-carved white granite [[Iraivan Temple]]. There is a black 16 Ton [[Nandi (bull)]] carved from a single stone in front of pavilion standing on redwood timber pavilion. Six-foot-tall black granite [[Murti]] of [[Ganesha|Lord Ganesha]] and [[Kartikeya|Lord Kartikeya]] are installed in two side shrines. Moreover lining the main walls of the temple is a rare collection of Shiva's 108 [[tandava]] dance poses in 16-inch-tall bronze icons covered with gold leaf. The shrine for the temple's founder, [[Sivaya Subramuniyaswami|Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami]] was established to the right of the entry door. A small temple tank has a bronze statue of dancing [[Sambandar|Saint Sambandar]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.himalayanacademy.com/monastery/temples/kadavul|title=Kadavul Hindu Temple|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
===Meenakshi Amman Temple, Madurai=== [[Meenakshi Amman Temple]] is a historic [[Hindu temple]] located in the south side of river [[Vaigai]]<ref>Editors of Time Out (2010), Hinduism: A Very Short Introduction, London: Time Out Guides Ltd., {{ISBN|978184670164-1}}., p. 194</ref> in the temple city<ref>Knott, Kim (2000), Hinduism: A Very Short Introduction, Oxford: Oxford University Press, {{ISBN|978-0-19-285387-5}}, section 10</ref> of [[Madurai]], Tamil Nadu, [[India]]. It is dedicated to [[Parvati]] who is known as [[Meenakshi]] and her consort, Shiva named here as Sundareswarar(beautiful deity). The temple forms the heart and lifeline of the 2500-year-old city<ref>National Geographic (2008), Sacred Places of a Lifetime: 500 of the World's Most Peaceful and Powerful Destinations, United States: National Geographic Society, {{ISBN|978-1-4262-0336-7}}., p. 155</ref> of Madurai.{{citation needed|date=August 2012}}[[File:Madurai-tank.jpg|thumb|right|Madurai Meenakshi Temple]]The centuries-old Sphatika Lingam held in this temple has developed cracks and hence a new six inch tall Spatika Lingam with the right specification has been brought from Himalayas. It is learned that this Lingam is worth over Rs.7.5 lakh. The new Sphatika Lingam will be the companion (Udaiyavar) to Lord Sundareswarar. The existing brass container of the Lingam will be replaced with golden container. The new silver consecration base (abhisheka peedam) weighing about 12 kg. is also getting ready for the formal [[consecration]]. The new Sphatika Lingam is getting consecrated on March 16, 2012.<ref>[http://www.hindu.com/2011/03/08/stories/2011030855230700.htm Temple gets new ‘sphadiga lingam']</ref><ref>[http://tm.dinakaran.com/pdf/2011/03/02/20110302a_002101005.htm மதுரை மீனாட்சி அம்மனுக்கு விரைவில் தங்க தொட்டில்]</ref><ref>[http://www.tamilmurasu.org/Inner_Tamil_News.asp?Nid=3009 மதுரை மீனாட்சி அம்மன் கோயிலில் ஸ்படிக லிங்கத்துக்கு மார்ச் 16 முதல் பூஜை]</ref>
===Ramanathaswamy Temple, Rameshwaram=== [[File:Rameshwaram.jpg|thumb|right|Rameshwaram Ramanathaswamy Temple Corridor]] [[File:Rameshwaram 2.jpg|thumb|right|Ramanathaswamy Temple Gopuram]] [[Ramanathaswamy Temple]] is a famous Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Shiva located in the [[Rameswaram island|island of Rameswaram]] in the state of Tamil Nadu, [[India]]. The Temple is also one of the 12 [[Jyothirlinga]] temples, where Shiva is worshipped in the form of a ''Jyotirlingam'' meaning "pillar of light". The temple is located in Rameshwaram, an island town in [[South India]], considered a holy pilgrimage site for both [[Shaivites]] and [[Vaishnavites]].{{citation needed|date=August 2012}} Ramanathaswamy temple was built during the 12th century {{citation needed|date=August 2012}} and widely expanded during the [[Thanjavur Nayak kingdom|Nayak]] period in the late 16th century. Ramanathaswamy temple is known for its longest corridor among all Hindu temples in India.{{citation needed|date=August 2012}}
In the first inner corridor, devotees offer worship to the venerated white Sphatika Lingam. The Sri Chakra (Sethu Peetam) and the Sphatika Lingam were instituted by the Hindu monk Adi Sankara. Sphatika lingam darshan is offered to the pilgrims during early morning hours i.e., morning between 5 and 6 am. It is a great experience.<ref>[http://xa.yimg.com/kq/groups/7138778/1021143114 Rameswaram]</ref>
===Ekambaranathar Temple, Kanchipuram=== [[Ekambareswarar Temple|Ekambaranathar Temple]] is a Saivite Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Shiva. It is located in [[Kanchipuram]] in the state of Tamil Nadu, India. Ekambaranathar Temple is the largest temple and is located in the northern part of the temple town Kanchipuram.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=oM2ZqMfg7hYC&pg=PA584&dq=ekambaranathar+temple&hl=en&sa=X&ei=HM0gT_vjA8PDgQfP0qztCA&ved=0CDMQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=ekambaranathar%20temple&f=false Let's Go India & Nepal] ed.8. 2004. Let's Go Publications. New York. {{ISBN|0-312-32006-X}}, p. 584</ref> The temple ''gopuram'' (gateway tower) is 59m tall, which is one the tallest ''gopurams'' in India.{{citation needed|date=August 2012}} This Saivite temple is one of the five major Shiva temples or Pancha Bootha Sthalams (each representing a primordial element) representing the [[Pancha Bhoota|element]] - Earth.{{citation needed|date=August 2012}}
The ursava deity Lord Ekambareswarar is seated in a glass sanctum sactorum with a roof decorated with rudraksha beads. Just in front of this shrine on the corridor, there another shrine with Sphatika Lingam along with the vehicle Nandi (Holy Bull). Offering prayer to this Sphatika Lingam will bring better appearance, confidence and fair thinking.<ref>[http://poomugham.com/index.php/bakthi/aanmigam/181-kanchipuram.html காஞ்சிபுரம்]</ref>
===Swetharanyeswarar Temple, Thiruvenkadu=== [[Swetharanyeswarar Temple]] is the Hindu Shiva temple located in the town of [[Thiruvenkadu]] near [[Sirkazhi]]. The prime deity is Lord Swetharanyeswarar (lord of white forest) or Lord Shiva and His consort is goddess Brahma Vidya ambal. There is a separate [[Sannidhi]] for Bhudhan (mercury (planet). The temple is quite larger premises and all four important Saivite saints have sung hymns in praise of this lord.{{citation needed|date=August 2012}}
This temple has one rare Sphatika Lingam. Special worship services are offered to Natarajar and the associated Sphatika Lingam, as in Chidambaram.<ref>[http://www.kudamookku.com/religious/navagraham/budhan-thiruvenkadu.htm Swetharanyeswarar Temple Thiruvenkadu]</ref>
===Sankara Narayanan temple, Sankarankovil=== Sankara Narayanan temple is located in the town Sankarankovil, Tirunelveli District and 56 km away from Thirunelveli City. It was built by [[Ukira Pandiyan]] AC 900. It houses the [[deity]] by the name Sankara Narayanan, which is half - Lord Shiva and the other half - Lord Vishnu. "Adi Thabasu" is main festival at this temple. In older times, the city was called as Sankaranayinar kovil. Even now it is called as Sankaran Kovil. The deities of this temple are Sri Sankareswarar, Sri [[Gomathi Amman]] and Sri Sankara Narayanar.{{citation needed|date=August 2012}}
Lord Shiva has agreed to perform consecration to Lord Vishnu. Therefore, consecration is performed to the Sphatika Lingam present inside the sanctum sanctorum. One view is that the Sphatika Laingam was instituted by Adi Sankara and yet another view states that the Sphatika Lingam was established by Sri Narasimha Bharathi Swamy of Shringeri Mutt.<ref>[http://www.heritagewiki.org/index.php?title=%E0%AE%9A%E0%AE%99%E0%AF%8D%E0%AE%95%E0%AE%B0%E0%AE%A9%E0%AF%8D_%E0%AE%95%E0%AF%8B%E0%AE%AF%E0%AE%BF%E0%AE%B2%E0%AF%8D,_%E0%AE%9A%E0%AE%99%E0%AF%8D%E0%AE%95%E0%AE%B0_%E0%AE%A8%E0%AE%BE%E0%AE%B0%E0%AE%BE%E0%AE%AF%E0%AE%A3%E0%AE%B0%E0%AF%8D_3 சங்கரன் கோயில், சங்கர நாராயணர் 3]</ref>
=== Shri Parkasheshwar Mahadev Mandir === [[File:Shri Parkasheshwar Mahadev Mandir Spatika Lingam.png|thumb|Two Spatika Lingam at Shri Parkasheshwar Mahadev Mandir]]Shri Parkasheshwar Mahadev Mandir is situated in the [[dehradun]] district, [[Uttarakhand]], [[India]]. It has twin spatika lingams.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://bugyalvalley.com/uttarakhand-tourism/dehradun/shiv-mandir/|title=bugyalvalley.com|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>

{{Chinese name|[[Song (Chinese name)|Song]]}} {{Infobox person |name = Sung Chi-li |image = |image_size = 200px |caption = |birth_name = Sung Kan-lin ({{zh|c=宋乾琳}}) |birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1948|9|17}} |birth_place = [[Xiaogang District|Xiaogang]], [[Taiwan Province|Taiwan]], [[Republic of China (1912–1949)|China]] |death_date = |death_place = |death_cause = |resting_place = |resting_place_coordinates = |residence = Taiwan |other_names = |known_for = Fraud |education = [[Tung Fang Design Institute|Private Tung Fang Junior College of Industry and Arts]] |employer = |occupation = |footnotes = }} {{Chinese|c=宋七力|p=Sòng Qīlì|c2=宋乾琳|p2=Sòng Gānlín}} '''Sung Chi-li''' (born 17 September 1948 ), born '''Sung Kan-lin''', is a notorious Taiwan [[occult|cult leader]] and [[geomancer]] who founded the Sung Chi-li Miracle Association and the Great Sun Sect. He was embroiled in a scandal in 1996 and accused of swindling US$7 million <ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tRLJCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA32&dq=%22sung+chi-li%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjAwc7Z_eLTAhVGE7wKHc3bBv4Q6AEIMDAD#v=onepage&q=%22sung%20chi-li%22&f=false|title=Development and Demographic Change in Taiwan (1945 - 1995)|page=32|last=Selya|first=Roger Mark|publisher=World Scientific Printers|location=Singapore|year=2004|isbn=978-9-8144-8378-0}}</ref> from his followers. He was convicted of fraud in 1997 and sentenced to seven years imprisonment.<ref name="TaipeiTimes2002">{{cite news|url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2002/12/11/0000186722|title=Cult leader for real, Hsieh's wife says|work=Taipei Times|date=2002-12-11|access-date=2017-05-10}}</ref> His verdict was later overturned in 2003 by the high court which cited freedom of religion was protected under Taiwan's constitution. Sung claims to have supernatural powers such as the ability to appear anywhere at anytime ([[Fenshen|fēnshēn]] body-double manifestations) <ref name="TheAustralian2008" /><ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=H-cRx-jjWtMC&pg=PA270&dq=%22Sung+Chi-li%22&hl=en&sa=X&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=%22Sung%20Chi-li%22&f=false|title=What Has Changed?: Taiwan Before and After the Change in Ruling Parties|last1=Fell|first1=Dafydd|last2=Klöter|first2=Henning|last3=Chang|first3=Bi-yu|page=270|publisher=Otto Harrassowitz Verlag|location=Germany|year=2006|isbn=978-3-4470-5379-2|access-date=2017-05-10}}</ref>), possessing divine healing powers and calls himself ''Yuzhou Guangmingti'' (宇宙光明體; lit. Cosmic Luminous Body).<ref name="Sinorama1996">{{cite journal|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cyPjAAAAMAAJ&q=%22sung+chi-li%22&dq=%22sung+chi-li%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjAwc7Z_eLTAhVGE7wKHc3bBv4Q6AEIKDAB|archiveurl=http://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:nX-eBIUmAHUJ:140.109.8.58/sinorama/content/ChEnIm.asp%3Fchptnumber%3D211110+&cd=3&hl=en&ct=clnk|archivedate=2017-04-29|title=Sung Chi-li Fraud Case Sparks Moves to Remove Criminal Element from Religion|work=光華畫報 (Sinorama Magazine Volume 21, Issues 8-12)|last1=Chen|first1=Marlene|last2=Wang|first2=Anna|page=51|publisher=光華畫報雜誌社|year=1996|access-date=2017-05-10}}</ref><ref name="TheAustralian2008">{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/archive/news/mystic-floats-into-taiwan-poll/news-story/9071e3c856174a7773f34eee61737c4f?nk=c5edf43310151d6532d76cb440c80173-1494372443|title=Mystic floats into Taiwan poll|work=The Australian|last=Callick|first=Rowan|date=2008-02-19|access-date=2017-05-10}}</ref>
== Early years == Sung was born in [[Xiaogang District|Xiaogang village]], [[Kaohsiung County]] in the [[Taiwan Province]] on 17 September 1948. He is the oldest of six children; four sisters and one brother. His father was very adept at making money and worked at a wholesale fish market. His family were the first in their village to own a television and telephone.
His eldest younger sister Sung Pao-lien (宋寶蓮) recalls Sung had developed [[mysophobia]] at the age of three and would eat in the corner and wash his own bowl and chopsticks. Their father had high expectations of Sung but Sung didn't like to study so their father would get angry and beat Sung with a wooden stick but Sung was very gentle, a boy of few words and didn't get upset nor talked back. Sung recalls it was at the age of seven that he saw a beam of light follow him. When he told his classmate, they'd laugh at him. When he told his father, his father said he is crazy. Sung became a social outcast due to poor grades and being abnormal.
After highschool, Sung left home and studied at [[Tung Fang Design Institute]], from that moment, he tried to seek answers and started to read [[Plato]] but couldn't comprehend it, then he read [[Socrates]] and [[Aristotle]] but still couldn't find an explanation for the beam of light he saw as a child.
After finishing [[conscription in Taiwan|military conscription service]], Sung's father gave him NT$1 million to start a shipping business at Taichung harbor. Sung worked there for nine and a half years. His sister, Pao-lien, said she always worried about Sung because he was too kind and not cut out for business so she was taken by surprise when he became a religious master.
=== Prison and change of career === Sung went into hiding for two years after writing a bad check and was later imprisoned for two years.
During Sung's time in jail he saw that beam of light outside the windows and says when he was being released from jail at the age of 39 he saw the three Chinese characters Sung Chi-li (宋七力) written in the skies and changed his name to it. It was during this time that Sung says he possessed the ''fenshen'' ability. In 1987 when [[martial law in Taiwan|martial law]] was lifted in Taiwan, Sung, who was 39 at the time and out of prison, saw an opportunity and began to hang around [[tea house]]s, talking and demonstrating his skills. As word spread about his abilities, he was noticed by someone who then spent large amounts of money to support Sung and helped him take photos. In 1990, Sung founded the Academy of the Union of Humans and Nature and began recruiting members in Taipei.<ref name="NTU" /> A year later he founded the Sung Chi-li Miracle Association ({{zh|c=中國宋七力顯相協會|p=Zhōngguó Sòng Qīlì xiǎnxiāng xiéhuì}}) <ref>{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/ASIANOW/asiaweek/96/1025/feat7.html|title=Passage|work=Asia Week|date=1996-10-25|access-date=2017-05-10}}</ref> and members believed Sung was greater than [[Buddha]] in his past life.<ref name="NTU" /> In the nine years leading up to 1996, Sung had amassed followers and supporters numbering in the tens of thousands in nine years, including financiers and politicians. At his prime, Sung would draw large numbers of followers who came and went in groups of cars. Sung would tip them tens of thousands of NTD. He recalls giving one elderly flower seller NT$50,000. He said when he was on the run for bouncing a check, his friend refused to lend him NT$500 and he vowed he would not to become a miser himself. The first time a Next Digital reporter, 賀照縈 (He Chao-ying), did an interview, Sung handed the interviewer an envelop containing NT$10,000 cash, telling him it was a gesture of good will that the reporter's boss need not know, to which the interviewer declined to accept the gift. At the last interview, Sung tried to give the interview and his three colleagues an iPhone 6 which they also declined. The interviewer noted Sung seemed desolate so he consoled Sung.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nextmag.com.tw/realtimenews/news/13183327|title=《後來怎麼了》彷彿若有光 1996年宋七力事件|work= Next Media Publishing Limited, Taiwan Branch|last=賀 (Ho)|first=照縈 (Chao-ying)|date=2015-01-16|access-date=2017-05-14}}</ref>
==Controversy== === Scandal === The scandal, known locally in Taiwan as the '''Sung Chi-li Incident''' ({{zh|c=宋七力事件|p=Sòng Qīlì shìjiàn}}), was first uncovered by [[Chu Mei-feng|Melody Chu Mei-fong]], then Taipei city councillor who accused Sung of conning disciples by selling them high-priced photos of him demonstrating his supernatural powers and that by worshiping the pictures, his followers could become a [[buddhahood|buddha]].<ref name="ChinaPost2002">{{cite news|url=http://www.chinapost.com.tw/news/2002/12/11/33053/Kaohsiung-mayor.htm|title=Kaohsiung mayor believes in fraudulent cult leader|work=The China Post|date=2002-12-11|access-date=2017-05-11}}</ref> She also accused [[Frank Hsieh]], who was legal consultant of Sung, of taking NT$16 million in political donations from Sung and that Hsieh's wife helped with compiling and publishing books for Sung. Sung and 16 defendants were then sued by former followers and he was indicted on charges of deception for obtaining NT$3 billion in donations <ref name="UCAN1996" /> by claiming to have supernatural powers by which he could help people.<ref name="TaipeiTimes2004" /> Sung was arrested on 13 October 1996 <ref name="UCAN1996">{{cite news|url=http://www.ucanews.com/story-archive/?post_name=/1996/11/20/government-religious-leaders-address-rampant-swindling-by-cults&post_id=8508|title=Government, religious leaders address rampant swindling by cults|work=The Union of Catholic Asian News (UCAN)|date=1996-11-20|access-date=2017-05-11}}</ref>
Due to a string of religious cult scandals making news headlines such as Sung Chi-li swindling NT$3 billion and Master Miao Tien swindling NT$2 billion, the [[Executive Yuan]] organized for the first time a forum to discuss the role and regulation of religion in Taiwan. The forum was held in Taipei on 8 November 1996 and attended by 110 senior government officials, religious leaders and scholars from 12 religious communities. The forum blamed the public's ignorance that allowed cult swindling to thrive.<ref name="UCAN1996" />
On 23 October 1997, Sung and two assistants Chen Cheng-tung (鄭振冬) and Lo Cheng-hung (羅正弘) were convicted of fraud. Sung and Chen were sentenced to seven years, while Lo was sentenced to two years prison. Frank Hsieh's wife and 13 others were acquitted of deception.<ref name="TaipeiTimes2002" /> During police investigations, Sung insisted he had supernatural powers and could make anyone do as he willed. Police challenged him by inviting him to demonstrate his powers in public but Sung failed to make a standing police offer to sit down. Sung's divine photos were proven to be doctored using basic computer graphic skills.
The case gained public notoriety when [[Frank Hsieh]], who was a lawyer and legal consultant to Sung at the time, and his wife Yu Fang-chih (游芳枝), were reportd to be long time followers of Sung. Yu went so far as to profess personally witnessing Sung's spirit leave his body at will. In 2005, Sung told [[TVBS]] cable news that in 2004 at a gathering in a follower's home, he had taken Hsieh on an [[astral projection|outer body]] tour of Paris with a stopover at the Eifel Tower where they could touch the cast iron.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sfgate.com/news/article/Guru-I-Took-Premier-On-Supernatural-Tour-2703135.php?forceWeb=1|title=Guru: I Took Premier On Supernatural Tour|work=SFGate|date=2005-01-27|access-date=2017-05-11}}</ref> Hsieh temporarily disappeared from the political scene after it was alleged he had taken inappropriate political donations from Sung and faced fierce criticism from the public over his membership in Sung's cult <ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2007/01/07/2003343727|title=NewsMaker: Election defeat proves no obstacle for Hsieh|work=Taipei Times|date=2007-01-07|last=Wang|first=Flora|access-date=2017-05-11}}</ref>
Sung admitted to police in charge of the investigation that he lied about having supernatural powers <ref name="ChinaPost2002" /><ref>{{cite newsletter|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UArcAAAAMAAJ&q=%22sung+chi-li%22&dq=%22sung+chi-li%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjAwc7Z_eLTAhVGE7wKHc3bBv4Q6AEIRTAH|title=The Cult Observer, Volumes 11-13|page=227|publisher=American Family Foundation|access-date=2017-05-10}}</ref> and police demolished the Miracle Association Memorial Hall, his Transmogrification Society's main shrine, on the grounds that it was built illegally. The shine contained faked photos of Sung in various states of ''fenshen'' which were used by his associates to fool followers into believing Sung's divinity. Sung also made donations to [[Political parties in Taiwan|political parties]].<ref name="Sinorama1996" />
In 1998, Sung founded a new religion, the Great Sun Sect whose members are believed to be in the hundreds but an accurate number has not been determined ({{zh|c=大日宗|p=Dà rì zōng}}) <ref name="NTU">{{cite work|url=http://www.ios.sinica.edu.tw/hyc/essay/9ROS/P301-338Religion_Occultism-8(Religious_attitudes).pdf|title=Religious Attitudes and Beliefs of Members of New Religions in Taiwan|work=Institute of Sociology, Academia Sinica & Department of Sociology, National Taiwan University|last=Chi|first=Hei-yuan|pages=336-337}}</ref>
=== High Court appeal === Although the scandal had almost hurt Hsieh's political career, he surprised everyone by winning the 1998 [[Kaohsiung City]] mayoral election despite being ridiculed and criticized for his link to Sung. The high court trial was reopened a few days after Hsieh's election victory.<ref name="ChinaPost2002" />
On 28 January 2003, the High Court overturned Sung's fraud conviction citing that the [[Constitution of the Republic of China|constitution]] protected Sung's practices under the freedom of religion which banned the law from defining and intervening in people's beliefs. This despite prosecutors pointing out Sung had admitted to lying about his mystic powers.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.chinapost.com.tw/taiwan/detail.asp?ID=34527&GRP=B|title='Mystic' acquitted by High Court|work=The China Post|date=2003-01-23|access-date=2017-05-10}}</ref> Under the protection of freedom of religion, the High Court decided that faith was more important than authenticity and that not only would it be difficult to prove Sung did not have supernatural abilities but that also accusers' testimonies were not sufficient to prove that Sung had defrauded them of money. Frank Hsieh was quoted as saying ""Religion cannot be analysed by reason." <ref name="TheAustralian2008" />
In 2004, with the financial support of his followers in Australia, Sung opened a US$3 million "divine photo shop" to display his divine photos.<ref name="TheAustralian2008" /><ref name="TaipeiTimes2004">{{cite web|url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2004/09/29/2003204824|title=Controversial guru opens `photo shop' in Kaohsiung|work=Taipei Times|last=Chuang|first=Jimmy|date=2004-09-29|access-date=2017-05-10}}</ref>
In an interview with [[Next Media]] in 2008, Sung says he is a [[mysophobia|mysophobe]] and has never had any sexual relations.
In 2015, [[SET News]] interviewed Sung regarding his supernatural powers,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_TYVejdfg20|title=數萬信徒風靡一時 宋七力分身術大解碼 (Deciphering Sung Chi-li's fenshen secrets which captivated tens of thousands of followers)|work=三立新聞台 (SET News Channel)|date=2015-07-13|access-date=2017-05-10}}</ref> the reporter asked Sung if he could demonstrate his powers especially his ''fenshen'' ability. Sung objected and insisted that only followers who have awakened their [[third eye]] could see the supernatural. He also demonstrated his abilities of being able to control his followers' bodies with his mind, to which his followers played along, but it had no effect on the reporter and cameraman. [[Next Digital]] also followed up and Sung admitted he is a controversial figure but that he was not afraid of punishment because he has no family and no children to worry about.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Odoin21rurI|title=你以為宋七力消失了？不，其實他還在 (Did you think Sung Chi-li had disappeared? No, he's still around|work=台灣壹週刊 (Next Digital)|date=2015-01-13|access-date=2017-05-11}}</ref>
